(Photo: Robert Deutsch, USA TODAY Sports) NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR SOCHI, Russia -- When Meryl Davis and Charlie White began skating together, she was so shy she couldn't even look at him, and coaches would have to put a sticker on his forehead so she'd have somewhere to look. He was annoyed as only a 9-year-old boy can be, forced to break someone new into a sport he'd already been doing for six months. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR It's fitting, then, that the ice dancers would give the United States its first Olympic gold medal in a figure skating event other than singles. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Still together after 17 years, they've outlasted many marriages. They're family now as much as skating partners and friends, and for all their considerable skill, they don't win gold Monday night without the love and respect they have for one another. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR "We've grown up together in every sense of the word," Davis said, "and I'm just so grateful that we were able to do it together." NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Being Olympic champions wasn't the goal when Davis and White teamed up. How could it have been, when the United States was still considered a backwater in ice dance? NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR It would take a change in the judging system in the mid-2000s to make North Americans legitimate medal contenders, and it would take a rivalry with another team committed for the long haul, Canada's Tessa Virtue and Scott Moir, to make Davis and White champions. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Virtue and Moir won the silver medal, their second of these Olympics. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Skating to Scheherazade, Davis and White may as well have been mirror images. Every extension, every turn, every expression of emotion was perfectly matched. Nowhere was it more evident than in their twizzles. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The rotating turns are incredibly difficult. Try rubbing your stomach and patting your head at the same time. Now try doing it in sync with someone else, and you get the idea. But Davis and White were so in sync they looked as if they were attached by invisible strings pulling them in the same direction.
